Ingredients

Safeway

  • 2 tablespoons extra-virgin olive oil
  • 1 ounce Italian salami, finely diced, or pulsed in a food processor
  • 4 cloves garlic, minced
  • 1 28-ounce can San Marzano plum tomatoes, drained, juices reserved
  • 5 or 6 fresh basil leaves, plus more for garnish
  • Pinch of sugar
  • Kosher salt and freshly ground pepper
  • 1 1/2 pounds frozen spinach-and-cheese ravioli
  • 1 ounce parmesan cheese, grated

Cooking Equipment

  • Casserole Dish/Pan

Cooking Instructions

  1. Bring a large pot of water to a boil.
  2. Meanwhile, heat the olive oil in a large skillet over medium-high heat. Add the salami and garlic and cook, about 1 minute.
  3. Crush the tomatoes into the pan with your hands and cook until slightly dry, about 5 minutes.
  4. Add the reserved tomato juice, basil, sugar, and salt and pepper to taste.
  5. Increase the heat to high and cook until the sauce thickens, about 5 minutes.
  6. Stir in 3/4 cup water and reduce the heat to medium-low. Let simmer while you cook the ravioli.
  7. Add salt to the boiling water, then add the ravioli and cook as the label directs; drain.
  8. Divide the ravioli among shallow bowls, spoon the sauce on top and sprinkle with the cheese. Garnish with more basil.

frontmatter.title: Spinach Ravioli
frontmatter.description: This post is related to the gatsbyjs
frontmatter.recipeIntroParagraph: The only spinach-and-cheese ravioli I could find at Safeway came in boxes of 12 ravioli squares, and cost about $8. Though I thought that was pricey, it was worth it. The taste of the cheese inside the ravioli was awesome with the tomato sauce recipe. This isn't a complex meal at all; it only took about 45 mintues. It's also great for leftovers.
